Introduction 

Paraphimosis (

figure 1
) is a urologic emergency that occurs in uncircumcised males when the retracted prepuce (foreskin) is trapped behind the glans.  This causes constriction around the distal penis, limiting venous and lymphatic outflow.  It presents with edema and tenderness of the glans and prepuce.  Without urgent manual reduction, paraphimosis can result in strangulation, vascular compromise, and necrosis of the penile tissue.

Pathophysiology



Prolonged or forced retraction can lead to entrapment of the prepuce behind the rim of the glans (the coronal sulcus).  Constriction around the distal penis limits venous and lymphatic drainage, causing edema and venous congestion of the glans.  Penile arterial flow may then be compromised; if untreated, lack of perfusion can result in ischemia and necrosis of the tissue.

Risk factors



  • Phimosis (
    figure 2
    ):  a tight prepuce that is difficult to manipulate over the glans; the small opening makes retraction difficult and increases the risk of entrapment
  • Improper handling of prepuce:  failure to promptly return the prepuce to its natural position after retraction; this may occur after glans cleaning, urination, genitourinary procedures (eg, catheterization), or genital examination 
  • Sexual activity:  commonly precedes paraphimosis in older patients

Clinical presentation



Paraphimosis typically presents with the following clinical findings:



  • Distal penile pain
  • Edematous and congested glans
  • Tight band of constricted foreskin proximal to the glans
  • Inability to return the foreskin to its normal position
  • Pink and soft glans (early), dark and firm glans if ischemic (late)
  • Normal, flaccid penile shaft
  • Decreased urinary flow or urinary retention may develop with severe edema

Diagnosis



Paraphimosis is a clinical diagnosis.  Uncircumcised patients who report penile pain and swelling should be immediately evaluated for this condition.  Physical examination revealing a tight band of retracted prepuce strangulating the glans confirms the diagnosis.

Differential diagnosis



  • Balanoposthitis (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ):  Inflammation of the glans and prepuce causes penile pain, swelling, and difficulty with prepuce manipulation.  A retracted, entrapped prepuce is not characteristic, and purulent discharge is commonly observed.
  • Tourniquet syndrome:  A hair or thin fiber becomes wrapped around the penis (or a finger/toe) causing severe pain, edema, and erythema at the site of constriction.  With careful inspection, the hair or fiber is often visible; examination of the prepuce can help rule out prepuce retraction and entrapment.
  • Penile edema:  Swelling can occur secondary to systemic diseases like congestive heart failure or renal disease (eg, anasarca).  Patients typically have known comorbid conditions, and the swelling is often symmetric and not isolated to the distal penis.

Laboratory evaluation and imaging



There are no laboratory or imaging studies required to diagnose paraphimosis.  The diagnosis is clinical, based on examination findings.

Management



Management of paraphimosis is emergency reduction, either manually or surgically, to maintain vascular flow to the glans penis.  Interventions include the following:



  • Manual reduction:  gentle, constant compression of the glans (eg, grasp and squeeze circumferentially) while attempting to pull the prepuce forward.  Topical and/or systemic analgesics are typically required; local anesthesia or procedural sedation may be necessary in some cases.  Application of hypertonic solutions (eg, sugar) to edematous tissue prior to reduction can help to draw out water and reduce swelling.  Treatment with ice reduces edema, but should be avoided if any evidence of ischemia is present because vasoconstriction may further limit penile perfusion.
  • Dorsal slit:  invasive surgical technique that is performed when manual reduction fails; involves incising the constricting band of prepuce
  • Circumcision:  may be considered after resolution to prevent recurrence

Prognosis



Prompt reduction of paraphimosis typically leads to good outcomes with no long-term sequelae, although recurrent episodes can occur.  Circumcision is the definitive treatment for prevention.  Delayed treatment may result in tissue ischemia and necrosis of the penis.

Summary



Paraphimosis is the retraction and entrapment of the prepuce behind the glans penis.  This circumferential constriction can lead to severe edema with vascular compromise.  The diagnosis is made based on physical examination, which reveals a tight band of foreskin strangulating the glans penis.  Immediate manual or surgical reduction is necessary to prevent penile ischemia and necrosis.
